He was engaged in advanced studies on quantum chemistry at Jilin University in 1965–1966 and 1978–1980. He was a visiting scientist at the University of Texas at Austin, USA in 1984–1986, at Keio University in Japan in 1991–1992, at the National University of Singapore in 1995–1996, and at the University of Georgia, USA in 2003. He was the Chairman of the Department of Chemistry of Fudan University in 1996–2003, a member of the Judging Committee for Academic Degrees of Fudan University, Chairman of the Chemistry Branch Committee in 1998–2012, and a member of the Committee for University Affairs of Fudan University in 2000–2006. In 2002 he was elected as member of the Scientific Board of the World Association of Theoretically Oriented Chemists (WATOC). In 2012 he was appointed as Deputy Director of the Steering Committee for Teaching of Fudan University. His research work won first prize for Progress in Science & Technology from the State Education Ministry in 2006. He has twice won second prize for State Excellent Teaching Achievement, in 2005 and 2009, respectively. His book Physical Chemistry won the first-class prize of the Shanghai Municipality in 2007. He received the State Famous Teacher Award in 2006 and the State Excellent Teacher Award in 2007 from the State Education Ministry. Xinhe Bao received his PhD in Physical Chemistry from Fudan University in 1987 and then worked as a fellow of Alexander von Humboldt in Frize-Haber Institute of Max-Planck Society in Berlin. He became a full Professor of the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1995. He is the member of Chinese Academy of Sciences, the member of the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World and the fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (UK). His research has been focusing mainly on the fundamental understanding of catalysis and its application in developing new catalysts and novel catalytic processes related to energy conversion, in particular, to clean coal and natural gas utilization. Recently, he pays much attention on the development of the novel concepts of the nano-confined catalysis and its application in selective oxidation of hydrocarbons and controlled conversion of syngas. Professor Guoqin Xu received his BSc in Chemistry from Fudan University in 1982 and his PhD in Chemistry from Princeton University in 1987. He was a postdoctoral fellow at Brookhaven National Laboratories (1987–1989) and a research associate at the University of Toronto (1989–1991). He joined the Chemistry Department of the National University of Singapore (NUS) as a lecturer in 1991 and was promoted to professor in 2004. He has served as Assistant and Vice Dean of the Faculty of Science (2004–2009) and Head of Chemistry at NUS (2009–2012). Currently, he is the Director of the National University of Singapore Suzhou Research Institute (NUSRI). His research interests include the surface chemistry of semiconductors and the fabrication and assembly of nanomaterials. Specifically, he has made significant and systematic contributions in organic functionalization of silicon surfaces and methodology development for nanomaterials synthesis, providing fundamental knowledge for designing and fabricating hybrid microelectronic chips, molecular sensors, and devices. He has published ∼190 papers in international journals with a total SCI citation of ∼4500.
